questions.text: Which of the following is the most common drug used in day care surgery/TIVA?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Propofol

  • Propofol is the preferred choice for daycare surgery and Total Intravenous Anesthesia (TIVA) due to its rapid onset and quick recovery profile. Additionally, Propofol is associated with a lower incidence of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV)

Propofol

  • Appearance: Clear, white emulsion, available as a 1% aqueous preparation (10 mg/mL) for IV administration.

Composition of Propofol

  • Chemical structure: phenol ring with two isopropyl groups.
  • Solubility: not water-soluble; available as a 1% aqueous oil-in-water emulsion.
  • Emulsion ingredients: contains soybean oil, glycerol, and egg lecithin.
  • Storage requirements: this should be administered within 6 hours of opening due to the risk of bacterial contamination, and a strict sterile technique is required
  • 0.005% disodium edetate or 0.025% sodium metabisulfite helps slow bacterial growth.

Pharmacokinetics of Propofol

  • Administration Route: only available for intravenous use.
  • Onset of Action: rapid onset; effects typically observed for 2–8 minutes after administration.
  • Distribution: short initial distribution half-life leads to quick awakening.
  • Recovery: faster recovery compared to other anesthetics, minimal "hangover" effects.
  • Biotransformation: high clearance exceeding hepatic blood flow (possible extrahepatic metabolism); metabolism occurs in the liver, resulting in inactive metabolites.
  • Excretion: Primarily eliminated via urine; unaffected by end-stage kidney disease.

Clinical Uses

  • Induction of Anesthesia: Suitable for patients aged 3 years and older; can be used in younger children with IV access.
  • Maintenance of Anesthesia: For patients over 2 months old.
  • Sedation:
    • During monitored anesthesia for various procedures.
    • For intubated, mechanically ventilated ICU patients.

Off-Label Uses

  • Management of refractory status epilepticus in both children and adults.
  • Treatment of refractory postoperative nausea and vomiting.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C and D are less commonly chosen for daycare surgeries

questions.text: Which of the following intravenous anesthetics functions as an NMDA receptor antagonist?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Ketamine

Explanation:

  • Ketamine is an NMDA (N-methyl-D-aspartate) receptor antagonist.

Mechanism of Action:

  • Inhibits N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor (NMDA) receptors (Option A), affecting the CNS.
  • Induces dissociative anesthesia, making patients appear conscious but unable to process sensory input.
  • Influences endogenous analgesic pathways.
  • High lipid solubility (5 to 10 times that of thiopental) and low protein binding (12%).
  • S(+) isomer (Ketanest) is 3 to 4 times more potent as an analgesic with fewer psychomimetic effects.
  • S(+) ketamine causes cognitive impairment and reduced reaction time despite its analgesic properties.
  • S(+) isomer has higher NMDA affinity and potency.

Pharmacokinetics

  • Absorption: Primarily given intravenously or intramuscularly; peak levels in 10-15 minutes.
  • Distribution: Highly lipid-soluble; rapid brain uptake with a 10-15 minute distribution half-life.
  • Biotransformation: Metabolized in the liver to active metabolites; tolerance develops with repeated use.
  • Excretion: Renally excreted; elimination half-life of about 2 hours.

Incorrect Options:

Propofol and Thiopentone (Options B and C) are direct GABA-A receptor agonists that enhance GABA’s effects.

Midazolam (Options D) is a benzodiazepine, increases GABA's effect by modifying the receptor to make it more responsive to GABA.

questions.text: Intravenous induction agent of choice for day care anesthesia is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Propofol

Explanation:

  • Propofol is the intravenous induction agent of choice for day-care anaesthesia due to its rapid onset, antiemetic effects, short duration of action, and smooth recovery profile. It allows patients to wake up quickly with minimal residual sedation, which is ideal for day-care procedures requiring early discharge.

 

Incorrect Options:

Ketamine (option A): While ketamine provides excellent analgesia and maintains cardiovascular stability, it is associated with slower recovery and potential emergence reactions (e.g., hallucinations). These side effects make it less suitable for day-care anaesthesia.

Etomidate (option C) has a rapid onset and is haemodynamically stable, but it is associated with adrenal suppression and myoclonus, making it less ideal for routine day-care procedures.

Thiopentone (option D) has a rapid onset, but its prolonged recovery time due to accumulation in body fat makes it unsuitable for day-care anaesthesia. It also lacks antiemetic properties, which are beneficial in outpatient settings.

questions.text: Sodium thiopentone is regarded as an ultrashort-acting drug due to (true or false)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Rapid redistribution

Explanation:

  • Sodium thiopentone (Thiopental) is a barbiturate used for induction of anesthesia. It is classified as an ultrashort-acting agent, and this characteristic is due to its rapid redistribution

  • Thiopental sodium has a rapid onset due to its high lipid solubility and high nonionized fraction, allowing for quick redistribution from the bloodstream to the brain.

Thiopentone Sodium:

  • Use: Intravenous induction agent.

  • Prepared concentration: 2.5% solution

  • Form: Yellowish-white crystalline powder or pale greenish hygroscopic powder

  • Odor: Garlic-like odor.

  • Formulation: Thiopental sodium for injection is a sterile mixture of thiopental sodium and anhydrous sodium carbonate (buffer).

  • Should not be reconstituted with lactated Ringer’s solution or mixed with acidic solutions, as this reduces alkalinity and may cause precipitation of the drug as free acid.

  • pH: 11

  • Melting Point: The free acid (thiopental) melts at 158–160°C.

  • Solubility:

    • Water: Soluble in 1.5 parts of water at 20°C.

    • Alcohol: Partially soluble.

    • Insoluble: Practically insoluble in ether, benzene, and petroleum ether.

  • Pharmacokinetics:

    • Higher potency.

    • Rapid onset and short duration of action.

    • Dose: 3-6 mg/kg

    • Duration of onset: 15-20 seconds

    • Duration of action: 6-10 minutes

    • Elimination T1/2: 12 hours (Option D)

    • Exhibits first-order kinetics.

    • Unique property: Duration of induction dose is determined by redistribution.

    • Metabolism: Liver (plays a role in elimination, not in the rapid offset of action) (Option B)

    • Excretion site: Kidney, (renal excretion is also slow and doesn't affect the immediate duration of action) (Option C)

questions.text: Which of the following intravenous anesthetics does not result in myocardial depression?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Etomidate

 Etomidate: · No effect on BP Cardiac output or coronary perfusion

Incorrect Options:

Options B,  C and D are incorrect. 

 Propofol,  Thiopentone, Ketamine are known to cause myocardial depression to varying degrees as part of their pharmacological effects. (all 3 act on GABA receptors)

Option B - Propofol: Propofol has a dose-dependent depressant effect on myocardial contractility and can also cause peripheral vasodilation, leading to decreased preload and afterload on the heart. Additionally, propofol can directly inhibit cardiac contractility by affecting intracellular calcium handling and reducing calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. 

Option C - Thiopentone: Thiopentone decreases systemic vascular resistance, which can lead to reduced preload and afterload on the heart. Additionally, it can directly depress myocardial contractility by reducing the sensitivity of cardiac myofilaments to calcium, impairing excitation-contraction coupling.

Option D-  Ketamine: ↑HR, ↑BP, ↑CO, Myocardial O2 Consumption

questions.text: Which of the following agents does not elicit pain on injection?
questions.solution:
Option A: Ketamine

  • Ketamine is known for its unique pharmacological properties, including its analgesic effects. It has a less painful injection compared to other intravenous agents.

 

Option B: Propofol

  • Propofol is associated with pain on injection. It can cause a burning or stinging sensation at the injection site. To mitigate this, propofol is often mixed with lidocaine or administered through a larger vein or with the use of a local anesthetic block.

Option C: Etomidate

  • Etomidate is also associated with pain on injection. It can cause discomfort and burning at the injection site. Similar to propofol, methods like dilution, premedication with lidocaine, or administration through larger veins can reduce the pain.

Option D: Thiopentone

  • Thiopentone can cause pain on injection. It is a barbiturate anesthetic and may lead to a burning or stinging sensation at the injection site. Techniques such as dilution or premedication with lidocaine may be employed to minimize the pain.

questions.text: Which of the following is the shortest acting local anesthetic?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Chloroprocaine:

  • Chloroprocaine is a local anesthetic with a short duration of action.
  • It is often used for short procedures and is suitable for regional anesthesia techniques where a rapid onset and short duration of anesthesia are desired.
  • Longest to shortest acting local anesthetics: Dibucaine (Longest) > Tetracaine > Bupivacaine > Lignocaine > Procaine > Chloroprocaine (Shortest)

Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to the use of morphine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Head injury:

  • Head Injury is an absolute contraindication for giving morphine.
  • As it further increases the intracranial pressure.
  • It masks the useful diagnostic & prognostic signs.
  • The effects of morphine such as respiratory depression, miosis & mental clouding also interfere with the diagnosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bronchial asthma: 

  • Bronchial asthma is not an absolute contraindication to the use of morphine.
  • However, caution should be exercised because morphine can cause respiratory depression and may exacerbate bronchospasm in susceptible individuals.
  • If necessary, alternative analgesic options may be considered for patients with severe bronchial asthma or a known hypersensitivity to opioids.

Option B - Renal failure: 

  • Renal failure is not a contraindication to the use of morphine.
  • However, in patients with renal impairment or end-stage renal disease, dosage adjustments may be necessary due to the potential for accumulation of morphine and its metabolites.
  • Close monitoring of renal function and titration of the dose are recommended in such cases.

Option C - Emphysema:

  • Emphysema is not a contraindication to the use of morphine.
  • However, caution should be exercised because morphine can depress the respiratory drive and may worsen respiratory function in patients with severe emphysema.
  • Adjustments to the dosage or consideration of alternative analgesics may be necessary in these situations.
